div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Qu'est ce que c'est BOVRIL?
BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
BOVRIL répare l'organisme fatigué.

div.head: EGYPTS MINING INDUSTRY
div.p: With respect to the numerous mining enterprises which have been inaugurated in Egypt, says the "Financier," the outcome, upon the whole, though not brilliant, is not discourag. ing; but the mineralised part of the country is of a character which demands thorough examination and stady. It appears in the highest degree probable that numerous localities will justify the employment of capital when sufficiently careful and systematic prog. pecting has been done. In this connection the establishment by the Government of a separate Department of Mines is of great importance, and it is to be hoped that a geological survey of the whole country will be proceeded with, with as much dispatch as the finances will permit.

The vast amounts of gold and other precious minerals which were found in Egypt in ancient times seem to have been all won from workinga the maximum depth of which was about 250 ft, and the great majority far less It is not to be supposed that under those conditions anything like an exhaustion of the ore-body was accomplished. Without any reasonable doubt, it may be assumed that vast quantities of valuable ores are still awaiting discovery, and at a moderate depth--in view of the ex ploits of modern mining - there will be plenty of payable ore brought into view before very long Up to now, however, the practical draw. back to Egyptian mining for the yellow metal has been the variable and uncertain yield of the ore. A vein has been struck which assayed exceedingly well, but which, on further examination, was proved to be of such a mixed character that the richness of any one cubic yard was little criterion of what might be in the

next. This description of deposit, though likely to yield many surprises, and a sufficient amount of excitement, is not the best for serious invest ment. It would, however, be rash to assume that, because this characteristic of Egyptian gold ore has been manifest, therefore the whole of the deposits of an auriferous description in all Egypt present similar features. Not a tithe of the country has been prospected in recent times, and if the Sudan be included, the vast ness of the area open to and inviting examination can scarcely be realised. That which may be true of one part of such a region is no guide to what may be found in another. Yet the prospector in the valley of the Nile bas at least one guide of considerable value. The country is in many parts honeycombed with the remains of ancient workings, most of which may be regarded as so many finger posts pointing down to possible riches below.

If ever the mineral deposits of Egypt become relatively anything approaching to the importance they achieved in the times of the Ptolemies, the country will once again be one of the very richest portions of the surface of the globe. Without anticipating any such outcome, it is quite permissible to surmise that the results of persistent examination may lead to the establishment of a mining industry of considerable proportions, which will become an important factor in the moulding of the country's destiny.

Given prosperous agriculture, an expanding mining industry and a rational and honest Government, it is obvious that Egypt will afford a multitude of legitimate openings for the employment of capital, and that for a very long period. How far this capital will be British is a question to answer which will be easier a quarter of a century bence, Meantime, French, Belgian, German and Italian interests in the country are being vigorously pushed It is not to be supposed for a moment that British capitalists and British corporations in Egypt are going to get the cream of the business going without let or hindrance. On the contrary, the country seems likely to remain, as it has been certainly ever since the time of Napoleon, something in the way of a battleground -not necessarily physical - for the nationalities of Europe, England has at the present time the advantage of to a great extent controlling the administration of the country, but this exceptional position is keenly resented, even yet, by other foreigners in the country, and no opportunities are lost of taking such action as is calculated to neutralise what is regarded as the undue authority of Great Britain. The only way in which British business interests in Egypt can be successfully maintained in the face of foreign enterprise is by the exercise of equal keenness and equal adaptability to the circumstances of the time and local environment.

div.head: ARAB STOICISM
div.p: Arab fatalism, which is at the root of his stoic impassiveness, though much talked of, is but little understood in its almost superhuman invincibility. This is brought into strong relief by the history attaching to a recent addition to the treasures of the Louvre Museum. It is a human skeleton & skeleton with a history. It is the disembodied framework of a man, an Arab and an assassin. In the flesh he was Suleiman el Aleby, and his hand it was that murdered Kleber, the commander of the French Revolutionary Army in Egypt. For this crime he was condemned by a French court-martial to have his right hand burned off, to be impaled and exposed to birds of prey, and to bave his body reduced to a skeleton. The burning off of his hand Suleiman bore without a groan or even a wince, but towards the end of the dire ordeal the executioner happened to touch another part of his arm with the red hot iron.
This punishment," he shouted with anger, is not in the sentence." Then he underwent the rest of the execution without giving any expression or even sign of feeling.

div.head: KHARTOUM'S NEW CHURCH
div.p: We bear that the Chorob of All Saints at Khartoum, on which work bas already pommenced, will be s magnificient pile. In the last number of the "Sadan Church Notes" Mr. Weir Sobultz, tbe arobitect of the new chorob, gives a devoription of the building. The plan is in the form of a Latio cross, the obancel being, as is oustomary, towards the Best and the pave to the West. The transepte, of wb cb there will be two, can be used separately as obapele. It has been soggested that the North trapsept beoalled the Gordon Memorial Chapel and that there abould be arranged various memorial panels which bave already been promised by friends of those who have fallen in the discharge of their doty in the Sudan.
The design for the church includes a detached tower of considerable size. It is hoped that this tower will contain a peal of bells and a clock.
The cburch will be built in stone and the Aror will probably be in marble and it is hoped to use some Sadanese marble for part of this The church will have a seating capacity of 600.
We learn from another soure that the total cost of the building may run to some L.E. 17,000 and that there will be no difficulty in finding the money to complete it as soon as possible.

div.head: THE SOLLOUM AFFAIR
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes :

Official ignorance is generally professed as to even the existence of a frontier question between Bzypt and Tripoli in Barbary. A certain sobool of jootnalism is blamed for ex*ggerating a simple feud between the frontier Bedouins into what appeared, at the time the Pomour was noi ed about, to be a serious disagreement between the Porte and the Anglo Byptian Government necessitating the services of another boundary ommission. The Assurance is given emphatically that no ground whatroever exists for alarm, effiial or other wise. The so-orl ed "oom mission" which it was supposed bad left to delimitate with the Tarkish authorities the frontier betwixt Ban gbazi Swejk and the Bebers, never quitted these bores ; moreover, wherever ligne de demarcation, to note the offioral terminology, separates--bowever vagnely-the arid wastes between the Oasis of Jarabob, was long ago marked out by Imperial Iradé. At least, so I was informed. The frontier line printed on certain maps Garman especially, is oaloolated to give one a falne impression, for høy allow Torke, eastward of Jarabub, a wider margin than what she is entitled to-and this is done
probably to please the Sultan.

As a matter of fact, the frontier rons from Solom southwards, direotly, passing close by the Ossis of Jarabub - wbich is Takish territory. The country is fertile only on the coastthe hinterland being, except for the oasis, al waterless xine, in which strategio movements on an extended soale are impossible ; benoe the rumoured massing of Ottoman troops is absurd. Indeed her sad experiences at Akaba

sbould make Torkey obary from any aggressive adventure such as she was lately supposed to meditate. The military importance, too, of Solam bas also been overrated. It might have bon stronghold in former days but at presect its strength is secondary and its garrison musters to more than forty.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
div.p: There was nothing remarkable about last night's "Aida" except its bois erous reception. No doubt the local colour and bistorical as sociations of this hardy annual are enough to call forth the extravagaot applause, which this very grand, very long, and, in our opinion, very depressing work invariably receives. The finish ing touch to yesterday's exaltation was given | by Sig. de Marobi's Radames, wbiob, though

the role does not suit him over well, gave us AS agual a throughoot vigorous and refined perfor Manor. That this would more or less dwarf the rest of the exponents was a fregno conolusion, It cannot be admitted that Sigos. Grisi was well ovet for the title role; neither voice por appearance come near to meeting requirements. Por all that she sang and acted with no small energy. Signs. Chotkowsks made an accurate and tasteful Amperie. The orchestra and oboros were well eno' gh, but the waits were again abominably loug, almost as long as the acts them elves.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL SHOW
FORMAL INAUGURATION
div.p: The formal opening of the Cairo Agricultural Show. took place yesterday afternoon at 9.80 p.m. A. the Khedive, the Ministers, Lord Oromer, the Advisers, the members of the Diplomatio Body, and Damerous bigh offisiala bad all arrived and were conducted over the exhibition by the leading members of the Kbadivial Agricultural Society. The Khedive took the greatest interest in the Show,of which be spoke in most complimentary terms, and we gather that the impression left on the minds of the other distinguished visitors wasmost favoor able. Daring the afternoon bandreds of persons of all nationalities and ages arrived, the tourist element being largely represented, and the shops where silk weaving, inlaid work, and other Byptian iodastries were carried on were benieged by dorious and interested peotators Wo imagine that another year the representa tives of provincial indestries wiil be lees sby of coming up to Cairo. Romour, indood, deolares that some of them absolately refused to exhibit till they had received their retorn tickets and a written guarantee that they would be refunded for the cost of the carriage of their stook 1 Some of them were doing an excellent trade by 3p.m. and we imagine that all will have made money by Maroh 4.

A few remarks anent the exhibition of native industries may be added to oor sommary of yesterday. Messrs. H.toun's kiosque contain of some magaifioeot examples of inlaid work, one table, going for « trif, of LR 190, sbowing an amazingly beantifal combination of geometrical designs in tortoise-sboll and mvher-of pearl. Abd Bl Salam Bt Homous sspi's stall was orowded, and we shald like to bear testimony to the readiness with which the representatives of the various orafte gove explanations of the processes involved in the manufacture of the artioles exposed for sale.

The Meha'la el Kubra silks and gheaper stoffa I were greatly admired, and we noticed some I good Assiout ware, black and red, in close proximity to the spot where the manufacturers of antiquities plied their trade. To do justice to the latter it must be said that the bead Decklaces which are sold for 38. to rosidonts and 5s, to tourists who do not bargaia con tain a very large proportion of genuine beads taken from mommy Gases aod tombs Thy pendants and the blue china bends are "recent," pot to say of yesterday's date, bat
very large proportion of the beads com posing the necklacus on sale is avoient enough.

The exhibition of specimens mounted and prepared by the laboratory staff of the Khedi vial Agricultural Society is extraordinarily interesting. Oatside the tent in which most of them are sbowa, are comparative samples of barley, wheat, and bersim grown with and without manuro or showing the noxious effects of the presence of souble salts in the soil. Within samples of the "T.A" olay and of the various pbosphates found in the country are sbowo, and with the method of extracting soluble salts, particularly nitrate of sods from T-A. This is efteoted' by passing water through
foor receptacles esob containing ground S T.A." The water issuing from the fourth is osobjooted to the process of ovaporation and o lesves a mixture containing above 50 per cent.
of soda. The entomological section oontains noxious insects of every species. First we bave the gorm carriers : the tré-te fly, wiob bests the parasitio-organism that OSONAS alonping
sickness, the common mosquito Oulos fatigare),

carrier of Bephantiasis and Pilariasis and perbaps dengue, and the yellow fover mosquito, wbiob bappily reserves itself for the task of transmitting the germs of this bigbly disagree able malady in the New World only. Then we have the insects and their congoners that

torment og and the beasts by direot attack, I tioks, gadflier, ramel flies, and horse flies, the irritating sandfly, whose living larve move in test tabes, and our friends, whom we do not name in polite socisty now that they have grown rare in the British I-les-we refer to Pulon irritans and Oimaa lectulariu (in literature the Ch mois-vide Mark Iwsin - and the Norfolk Howard - vide Victorian literature passim).

Lesving those affectionate orantures we turn to the enemies of ontton and other drops-the Bollworm moth (Barias insulana) and ita metamorphoses, the notorious cotton moth and its larvae, the small green cotton worm (the larvs of a pretty little brown and silvary grey moth known to scientist Caradrina exigua, and the out worm. Other cotton posts sbowe are the cotton stainer, whioh mata and soils the fibres and pieroes the goods with its beaklike mandibles, the oottoa" apbris, which suck the sap from the leaves, various TASboppers and the migratory looost, and the American, cotton-bag, whioh bu bappily not yet appeared here. The moths that attack herim are idential with the enemies of cotton, bat sogar onde has a special fe in the "borers," whose ravages are shown in a series of ex cellent photographs. The lebbek beetle and the egg plant borer (the larva of tiny moth with an immense name) and their misdeeds are on view, and to bring to copolosion this desoription of an entomologioul obamber of horrors we note with gret the presence of the lovely tailet copper butterfly |(Hypolycaena livia) food gnity of destrrying pomegrauates in it-wingless yooth. Just as in Mme. Tangenud's we see first the waxen oriminals and then the axes, books, gallows, nooses, and instruments of torture that have overtaken them, so here a fine colleotion of insecticides And the apparatus for employing them is on view.

The botanioul section must next be considered. Interesting diagrams illastrate tho Mon Collon law of boredity as applied to the cotton plant. We have the resalts of orossing betwoon Isng and shorter fibred varieties and of a va riety of other crosses. Fongoid growths which kill or injure the plant are showa, among them the highly freqnent "sore shin," whose ravages aro illostrated by half a dozen capital preparations. Young plants are shown freshly attaoked, dying and ded, and a sheet of felt interwoven with the long filaments of the fangos which after a yosr's droaght will reappear should its ridus be moistened.

A few additional remarks must be made about the live-stook. The oamels are almost all, if not all, baggage animals, good of their kind bat loss picturesque than the 'bagims" of the desert. Asses are rare ; the poultry and pigeon exbibits are small, bat we notioed some fine fowls of the Fayoum breed and Cyprus cook vrith two bens which bore a great resemblance to the well-koowa Black Spanish." Among the sheep the very prettily marked "Hagazi" breed, three or four of which are exhibited by Captain Flower, are very noticeable. The horses and cattle are qaite ap to the mark, though the visitor accustom i to British and Continental abows would note with grief that the average native exhibitor has little or no idea of how to I prepare bis beasta for exhibition. They come op as they are, clean or dirty, and in the onse of sheep and horses more especially this want of attention greatly detracts from the appearance of the animals, however good their breed.

ning North and South, bezinning with the treat next to the British Barracks, which shall be called "No. 2."

In addition to their nambers the following streets have been ropamed: "Abdel Aziz" 8t. in to be oslled "Melik Avenue," Momtaz Pasha" 3t. "Saltan Avenue," "Mouss Pasha" St. "Kitabener Avenue," "No. 18" 8t "Gordon Avenue," "Mohd. Ali" 8t. "Mobi. Ali Avenue."

Streets ronning diagonally will be named but not numbered as ollows: "Gadid" Kerreri" "Atbara" "Abu Hamed" fir" Pirket" "Roseires" "Gedaref" Toks," "aba Klas" Metem na" "G:nnis" Sinkst" Toski" and "Tamsi."

markets will be called "Market Square." "Abbas Saare" will retain its prosout same.

div.head: "THE DEAN'S BUILDING"

div.p: The foundation stone of the new Bogliob School at Gezirot Bedrano, Cairo, better known I cally as the "Dean's Baildingo," wa Jaid on Wedoosday afternoon by the Countess of Cromer

The school building will oooupy 800 quare metres of land, and staod two storeys bigb. Oo the ground floor there are to be two sobool. rooms, obapel, library, and tesober's Apart ments. On the opper floor, the dormitorios. The utmost onre has been taken in regard to sanitation : a proper sewage disposal system is to be fitted op by the engineer, M. André Tissier, who bos similarly installed the Con tinental and the Savoy. The building is being erected by the Beyptian Construoʻions, Ltd., and the name of M. Loyek, the arobiteot, inspires confidence. Bluontionally sperking, this school will supply a long felt want of growing community. Already there is nucleas of forty obildren, under Miss Koer,

be religious ceremony on Wednesday, 000dooted by Bishop Blyth, was simple, yet im. pressive, and watobed with respeotfal interest by a goodly gathering of Datives. Among others present we notioed G eral and Mrs. Ballook Dr. and Mrs. Madden, Mrs. Butober, Mr. and Mrs. Possman, Mr. and Mrs. Jobo Walker, Rev. C. P. Thomas, Rev. Gairdoer, Rev. McIones, eto.
The Rev. J. T. Barne read the following | address :

"B-fore the service begias I must say a few words about the object of our meeting here. You have been invited to witoess the stonelaying of the Deau's Baildiog. I bave sent potioos to members of the Chorob Committee and the members of the Rsilway Institute Committee and to those who bavo in the past shown an interest in our efforts to establish | 8o Boglieb School in Cairo. For more than year we have been trying to acquire land for this purpose, tbe broat of this labour falling on tbe Dess and Mrs. Batober; owing to being without « soboo! bouse for Ostober, extra efforts were made, and this parool of land was discovered by Mr. Brreaux. The land was bought for £1,000 by Mr. John Wal. ker, who is most kindly giving us his services. Mr. Layek, the arohiteot, bas takon groat pains to exaotly supply what is required, and after receiving several tenders We fioally accepted that of the Bryptian Constructions Company. The total cost of the achemo is estimated at £4,000, which is being borrowed at 4 % The building will consist of school premises, a large room for services and Banday sobools convertible into two sobool rooms for woek days, « flat whiob must at

present be let, but whiob, it is hoped, will, when fonds sllow, be used ma small orphanAge, flat for the head-mistress, and a ftit for the assistant obaplain of All Saints': thus the annual obarge of interest and other expenses will be met by rents and two additional grants, and it is hoped gradually to pay off the ospital a obarge and so establish it on a more permanent, M ba-is. Our most grateful thanks are due to the p Barl and Counters of Cromer and Mrs. Poote A for their dever failing interest and bo'p in our work, and to Lord Blward Ceoil sod Lt. Col. b Macaulay for the kind assistanon they have a rendered as. Lastly, when onr late beloved Dead resigoed it was his wish that his last publio act in Egypt should be to condoot tho E service of this stone laying and we bave felt that it would be in kosping with the general wish that this building should bear his loved and honoured Dame."
Lady Cromer plaoed in an iron soffer which was soldered down, a document bearing the following dedication :
"This is called the Dean's Building in memory of Charles Henry Batober Desu of Shanghai Cathedral and Arch teacon of Egypt and 26 years Chaplain of All Saints.
"Io the reign of his Majesty King B1ward the Seventh, King of Great Britain and Ireland, Emperor of Ladis, &o, &o.
His Highness Abbas Hilmi II. Khedive of Egypt.

"His Excellenoy the Right Honourable Earl of Cromer, G.C.B., G.C.MG., K.C.SI.,! 0.M , His M jesty's Minister Plenipotentiary Agent and Consal General in Egypt. In the year of our Lord One Thousand Nioo Hundred and seven the Twenty seventh day of February this stone was well and truly laid by Katherine Counters of Cromer.
The owners of this house are the Chap laio and Assistant Chaplain of All Sainte Charob in trast.
"This building was designed by L Loyek, B q., of 2 Chareb Cherif, Caire, and constructed by the Egyptian Contruotions, Limited, of Cairo and Alex.
andria." After the stone had been laid, Lord Cromer made the following remarks:
"It has been a great pleasure both to her ladyship and myself to be present here to day.
It is a source of special gratifruation that this d building sbould bear the name of our lato dear pastor. I am sure there oould not have been
more fitting memorial to him than the facility that afforded for the ruostion of * English obildren in this country. There is one
more remark I think I should like to make. Mr. Barna in bis add eis made do allusion to bis own efforts in connection with the institution of which the foundation stone bus just been laid.
I think it is only fair to say ile be bas been d extremely usefol, ayd deserves vraise aud
the thanks of the whole British commodity. I will close by wishing the sobool overy 1000088."

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Rathmore, whose interesting speech at the meeting of the Bank of Egypt appears in another columr, is an Irishman and hold 1 ono of the five poorages of the Plapkott or Planket family, the others being Dansady, Fingall, Loath, and Planket. He was born in 1888, the third son of the third Baron Plunket and of the daughter of the Rt. Hon. Charles Basbe, Lord Caief Jastice of the King's Bench of Ireland. He was edaosted at Trinity, Dablin, and onlled to the Irish Bar, Prom 1876 to 1877 he was Solicitor General for Ireland and repremented Dablin University in the House of Commors from 1870 to 1896, when he was breated Baron Rathmore. He is a baobelor and hos no heir to his title. His brother was the late Archbishop of Dablin. Lord Rathmore lives at Wimbledon.

El-Lova Henry Pasba, Adjatant General, is expected to rerob Khartoom this week. After spending about 15 days there be will return to England to take s post in the British Army in which he now holds the rank of Major General.
Daring his stay in Khartoum, His Beatitade the Greek Patriargh will osoapy Messrs. Stamatopoulo's hoone on Sirdar Avenge, which has been rented and fitted op by the Greek Committee for this parpose.

Colonel Chaarand, of the Italian Army, has been on a short visit to Khartoum coming from Erythren. He visited the Gordon College and the Military School and was well impressed by the work of these two institutions. Colonel Chaarand is now in Cairo.

div.head: GAMBLING IN CAIRO
div.p: "Al Moayad" is now osrrying on a vigorous Campaign against so-called Billiard Olub which it terms " thinly disguised gambling den" and an even more notorious establishment of the same sort recently opened in Clot Boy. street, Cairo. In this connection Selim" remarke- W. de-ire to save the incomes, the health, the intelligence, and the dignity of our young people and government employée. We wish to guarantee them the quiet rost in their own homes wbioh gambling and the gambling spirit annihilate. Sleep, rest, and relaxation are indispensable our young people do not enjoy any of them; they gamble instead. Gambling is degrading-benos por attacks on it. Thousands are aware of the foot, but their lack of will power prevents them from resisting the temptation to play just one more time. The Government, which is allpowerful, can remove at least the onuses of temptation, and we argently demand ita in tervention. It is only by oonstant insistance on the subjaot that we see any chanog of bringing about the suppression of sob ostabliebmants and the resistance to their lores. Woonn only save individuals by pointing out to them the golf of rain that always gapo for them and foroing the dangot upon their attention. They may be convinced that * are noting for their good. Their wives and ohildren, their parents and dependente, oven their offioial chiefs, cannot bat approve our campaign."

We understand that the gaming houses referred to by our contemporary are in the occupation of a Spanish subject, who is nosinted, at least in the Clot Boy gambling olub, by several Andalusian, girls who are doubtless sofficiently charming to persuade young and
susceptible panters to remain till their last of piastre has gone.

While it is premature to indicate the definite lines of the Anglo-Russian agreement the negotiations are making satisfactory progress, one tangible result of which was the joint offer of a loan to Persia. The non-acceptance by the latter does not aff at the new attitude of the two Governments to one another. The progress of the negotiations naturally creates an atmosphere of conciliation extending to Rosso Japanese negotiations.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE REICHSTAG.
CHANCELLOR AND GERMAN POLICY

div.p: The Liberal and Conservative papers praise the cleverness of Prince von Balow's speeob, which was directed against the Centre and the Socialists. Herr Bebel's speech, which lasted three hours, made no impression. Even the Opposition newspapers acknowledge that Prince von Bulow repelled the attacks of Herr Bebel with the same BUODB88 as the attacks of the Centre. .

The newspapers, in giving details of the sitting of the Reichstag, lay stress on the bitterDess of tone with which the Chancellor charaoterised the Vorwaerts" statement that Ger many had the intention of threatening the British possessions of South-West Africa as a base calumpy and said that such stupidity accounted for the opinion spread abroad that the electoral victory of the Government would be a danger to peace.
The Press approves of the explanation that Pridoe von Balow has given of the detest of the Socialists in attributing it to their interna tional sentiments,
(Reuter)
A most formidable bomb was found yester day on the railway between Tssrekoe Selo and bere, just prior to the passing of train in which the Grand Dake Nicholas was travelling.
Seventeen persons were tried by court martial and hot yesterday for complicity in the riots at Tukkun near Riga in 1906. (Router)
The General Staff has ordered the first part of General Kuropatkin's report on the war to be distributed among the higher ranks of the army.
(Reuter

div.head: BANK OF EGYPT
ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING
div.p: The twentieth ordinary general meeting of shareholders of the Bank of Egypt, Limited, was held on Friday, February 15th, at the offices of the bank, Mr. George T. Biddulpb (shaira an of the company), presiding.
The Chairman called on the Beorotary (Mr. Arthor Niobola) to read the notioe calling the meeting, the minutes of last general meeting and auditors' report.

The Chairman : If you plesse, we will take the report and statement of accounts as read. I think you have all had a copy of it fut some days. (Hear, hear. Woll, gentlemen, I am glad to have the privilege of addressing you to-day and submitting our fifty first report, because it is a very gratifying one. Io looking back at the balance sheets, taking them from the commencement, as I have done, up to the present time, you fiad a gradual improvement all the way through, and, although this last year has not shows a vast improvement on the previous year, still, whatever changes have taken plase are all to the good, and therefore I may sately say that it is the very best balance sheet that has ever been pat before thesbareholders of the Bank of Egypt. Of course, I do not for a mi Dute wish to say that there bave not been causes of anxiety daring the past year. We cannot always be free from them, and when you consider the great expansion of business that there has been in Egypt and the new companies that have been started, which bave caused a good deal of speculation in shares; and, again, the great increase in the value of lands in Bgypt, which bas produoed large profite made very rapidly, it natarally entails considerable anxiety apon those who lend mo ney to their clients, as you may well imsgine. There is another cause of anxiety wbich I think has been folt everywhere, and that is the high Bank rate, wbiob, in Ostober, was raised to 6 percent. This, of coure, was caused chiefly by the amount of gold that was sent out by this country to Egypt and to other countries. Take Egypt alone, where as a role we send out five millions a year, this year we send as much as nine millions or more-that is foor millions inexoss. This was not caused entirely, as was supposed, by speoulation in land or in shares, but by the great inorenne in the value of cotton and the abundance of the orop. This year's orop is about a million oantars of cotton more than in the previous year. Tae custom in Egypt, which perhaps you are not aware of, is that the producerselis his cotton always for cash, and not against drafts. The cotton bas to be paid for in ballion, and therefore wben tbe produoer this year took advantage of the bigb price of cotton and sold in Ooto ber, instrad of holding on, as he generally dous, until later in the year for better prices, everyone was at his wits' end to find tbe ballion which had to be sent down to the provinces to pay for it. That is the real reason of the great demand for ballion towards the end of the year so far as Ezypt was ooncerned. There is no doubt but that the amount of cotton sold in Egypt has been consider ably greater than in any previous year, and also that prices bave been exceedingly good, averaging about yd. per lb. more. I should like you now to turn to the balance-abeet. I do not koow that there is much in it on whíob I need comment, except that on the

liability side the bills payable amount to £1,676,000, which is a decline of £ 4,000, wbiob, of course, is satisfactory. The or rent accounts are £1,176,000, wbich is a bighly satisfactory Dorease of £268, 289, and the net profits come to £'36,760 which is practically the same as last year. If yoq will turn to the other side of the account, you will see that the cash balance i £118 091, which is £47 671 more than at this time last year, and the bills receivable sbow a decrease of £186,697. This is owing to the fact that when our counts were made op it was the middle of the cotton season, and every penny was required for the use of the orop, and remittano s were only made to cover what was absolutely required. No doubt you wil like to know that wa bad at Alexandria on December 31st £400,000 worth of cotton, and In the provinces we had £450,000 worth of cotton, so that we had nearly a million in produce lying in our depós on December 31st. With reference to our investmente, which are put down at £146,000, the greater part (£265,000) are actually British Government securities, and the balance is in Egyptian Government Guaranteed bonde, wbioh are considered equivalent to British Government securities. The valuation of these soonrities on December 31st shows a large margin to the gard, which is also satisfactory festare. With reference to the bank pre mines, you will ree that they have been increased to £59,00), which is an increase of £21,000 over laut year. This is accounted for by the fact that we have built the bank a Port Said, which cost us £9,756. Lord Ratbmore, who bas jnst come home, will be able to tell you what sort of a building we have put op, but it is in every way a credit to the bank. We bave also spent £11,000 on the porobase of land and agency bailding at Mansourab. From the above amount we have written off £6,048 9s. 8d., leaving £53 0 O carried for ward as representing our bank premises. These are a very valuable asset, representing pro perty in Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Benisourf. Khartoum, Mansoorah, Damar hoor and Fayoum. As you are doubtless aware, the extraordinary increase in the value of land and property in Egypt in the last two years is such that I need hardly tell you that our properties represent a very considerable cum beyond that figare. You may take it that it is a very valuable asset to this company,

asked by an old woman what age be sopposed her to and be replied promptly that be declared to Heaven be did not know what age she way, but whatever age she was she didn't look it. (Lyoghter.) That is very much the case with our Pasba; he is in very good health, and be looks a great deal batter than he did five years ago, and I heartily hope that we may bave his services for some time to come. (Hear, bear.) I am sore he will goide us through any difficulty that may arise of a temporary kind in Bgypt with great skill and prudence. Then, a thu obairman bas said, be is very ab'y supported by our other offisers at Csim, at Port Said, at Khartoum and elsewhere. I was not able to go to Kbartoum myselt, but I had the advantage of an interview with our manager there, Mr. Lnard, a very sapsble young gentleman, who bappered to be passing throngh Cairo. and from what I have beard from him and from others well acqusinted with the present state of Upper Egypt, I am satisfied that wit bin Acme little time it may take some years for its complete fulfilment there will be a great advancement and wonderful opportunities for business in Kbartoom and its neighbouring regions wben the effects of the improvements in irrigation which are now going on in fertilis. ing lands have been more fally completed, and when the gaps in the population which enfor tanately were left by the barbarous role of the Mahdi have been filled up, and when there will be a larger number of people to produce agricultoral results. No one can doubt that there will great field, and a very favourable field, for the operations of a bank like oors, and at Khartoum, as in other places, I am glad to think oor bank stands very well and is very popular with the people fof the cour try of all kinds. Then as to Port Said. A our obairman has said, Port Said hwobanged in a most marvellous way. The last time I was there there were shabby Bryptian villages bat now there are splendid buildings of ovey kind and every sigo and tokeo of a great spread of prosperi y and wealth. I am very glad to ser, in view of that, that the bank which we have lately built ther, at a onet of £9,700, is really one of the finest in Port Said, and splendidly arranged for banking perposes. And remember, gentlemen, bailding and bank premises, as the obirman bas nid, are a constantly improving investment for us Por instance, our provost book buildings in Cairo

The Chairman : It is a delioate question, but I may say that he has been in our service for 45 years. He came to us as quite a young man, bat be is still toll of extraordinary energy, and his knowledge of the people is of very great importance and value to the bank. I am also glad to say he is well supported by the staff. We have, unfortunately, lost daring the year the services of Mr. Greville, who had | boop our manager at Cairo, bat who has obtained a better post elsewhere. We are sorry to lose one who filled that position so long. His place has been filled by Mr. Davidson, who did good work at Khartoum for us, and Mr. Laard, who was working for us at the agency at Soakin, has been transfarred to Khartoum. I hardly like to speak of our staff here in their presence, but they all deserve the same oredit that we give to those abroad. Perhaps Mr. Nichols will pardon my reading « letter I received from a shareholder, who is unable to be present here to day. He writes strongly supporting as in every way, and he adds: "I should like also, if I may do so, to express my 80080 of the antailing courtesy of your Secretary, Mr. Niobols, bis readiness to afford *y information that it is in his power to give, and the genial reception that shireholders always meet with at his hands must render in

great pleasure to have any communication with him." I think that speaks volame. He says: "I would not have written this if I had been able to come myself to the meeting." Your shares are very well distributed over a very large number of shareholders. A very short time ago we had only 600 : Dow we have 1,86%. That, of course, inorenses the work of the effije very considerably. Then I should mention that. Lord Grenfell and Mr. GH. Palmer, who is in Egypt, retire by rotation and you will be asked very sbortly to re-eleot them. You will be also asked to appoint Lord Milner as an additional director. I think that will meet with the approval of you all. Lord Milder, you know, is a very great financial expert. He was secretary to the late Lord Gosoben when Chancellor of the Exobeqaer ; be then became the Chairman of the Inland Revenge in this country; he then went out As Financial Seoretary to His Highness the Khedise in Egypt ; and therefore be is wellkuowa in that country, and very much respaoted by everyone with whom he has come in contact. We think that we are most fortunate in obtaining his consent to join the board. I will not detaia you any longer, but will move : "That the report and statement of accounts to December 31st, 1906, now presented to the sbareholders, b, and they are hereby, received and adopted, and, in conformity with the recommendation of the direotors, that a divi. dend at the rate of 10 per sent. for the your ending December 31st, 196, be and is hereby declared (es the io terin dividend at the rate of 4 per cent. on 80000nt thereof paid on July 141h last), apd also a bongs of 204 per share, 8 per cent., to be payable on February 16th, 1907." I will oall apou Lord Rathmore, who has recently returned from Egypt, to second the resolution.
Lord Rathmore : I beg, at the invitation of our obairmao, who has given you such a clear and satisfactory mooount of the working of the bapkw it appears in the report wo bavo sab

mitted to you, to cond thio resolation, and it gives me great pleasure to AL you, as the resalt left apon my mind by the visit wbiob I lately paid to Baypt-where I spent the month of JADINY-that the presente position and immediate prospects of our bank are very encouraging. I was much strook by the extra ordinary inores e in the prosperity of Bgypt whiob has taken place since I was lost there about eight years ago. To anyone who has not seon that advance it would really seem almost inoledible, but I could, however, easily prove it if I were to go into official figores on the sabject. Bat I should like to say, in reference to rumours, whiob, no doubt, you bave seen in some newspapers at home, of possibilities of danger and impending commercial orash there, that, having had the opportunity of speaking to a great many men well ospable of forming an opinion on soob matters in Egypt, I think that these rumours and warnings are somewbst exaggerated. There is no doubt, as our obairman asid, a certain amount of rather wild speoulation -saob speculation as I believe usually accom panies a rapid development of sound business

there is a certain amount of gambling going 00, especially in the wonderfully rapid increase in the value of land, and I suppose there is no doubt that if there were suddenly to ome a financial diffi yalty of any kind a good many of th 999 Wild speculators and gamblers might go to the wall. Bat there is no doubt that, besides that speculation, great preponderance of the busines now being done in Egypt is of a sound obaracter, and would pro bably proceed on its coarse very little affected by the misfortunes which might happen to individuals. There might be for a time very anpleasant ones, bat I think, on the whole, the steady progress of the country would pro ceed. The omm groial developments of every 1 kind are extraordinary, bat especially in the value of land. Bveryone foresees that the prosperity which has already come opon Egypt within recent years is but an earnest of what is still to come, only they say that this land, valoable as it is now, will soon be more vala able, and so they go on baying and selling, and, of course, there must arrive & moment when they cannot get bayer at a higher price and then will come a squeeza for the people who have been rather reckless over their transActions; but, as I have said, I do not think that can be regarded as likely to inter tere to any great extent with the general progress of the country, and I am quite sure we sball be most osrefully and 080tiously guided by Mr. Lazzato bog his pardon, I ought to have said His Excel lenoy Lazzato Pasha--but I remember him more as an old friend than a new dignitary. (H98r, bear). As the chairman has said, be is not only, as you all know, . very able mso, who has contributed so much to the prosperity of our back, bat be has also an extraordinarily intimate koowledge of the country, and he thoroughly understands the situation. Besides that, be has an enormous number of friends all through Egypt, from whom he is always receiving information at first band. He knows very well who of our clients are going too fast ahead, and he knows those whom be dan safely trust. In that way, I quite apart from his great ability, he bas speoial advantages in directing our business. He bas a great pride in the bank, to the success of wbiob be hus oontribated so largely, and I am glad to say be is in ospital beslih. Some gen tlems asked what his age was. Well, really, I do not know, but I am inclined to answer, as a countryman of mine did, an Irisbman who was

-the house itself is not very well bailt, bat the site is . ospital 030. I bad the plouare, with the assistance of my noble friend, Lord Greufell, of ohooolog that site some eight years ago. I think we could sell it now for many times what we paid for it. I was talking of Port Said and I may my that the Suez Canal Company, of which I happen also to be a director, are making great improve monte in that port. The sobeme is to make new barbour near the mouth of the canal, in which the colliers, wbiob now to a considerable extent orowd to estrano, will be set on One side, and thus the fairway entering the ongal will be greatly improved. There will be a great development of looal enterprise at Port Said, on account of the over-inoreasing pomber of ships passing through making market for the merchants and tradesmen of Port Said. Besides that, it is the opinion of some well goalified to form an opinion that large part of the development of Lower Beypt will come to Port Said, - the exit from Alex. andria Harbour is not, I believe, so good for ships going out into the Mediterranean. Therefore, I am very glad that we have lost no time in placiog ourselves firmly in a very suitable and fine building at Port Said. Not only are our general manager, Lozzetto Pasha, and all our offisers working with the greatest zoal, but they are very popular with the people with whom they have to dosl. lo faot, witb. ont putting the thing too rosily, our present position and immediate prospects are deoidadly favourable. Or course, I have said, there may be some moments of anxiety, bot only for this bank, but for other people in Egypt, bat, on the whole, the progress of the country is more like a fairy tale than anything else, and I believe is of very sore kind. Therefore, unless some great misfortune, at present quite apforesoon, arises, we may look forward with a fair amount of confidence to the results of the current year being good. I have much pleasure ia seconding the rosolation. (Applause)
The Chairman : Has any gentleman ady question to ask?
A Shareholder: Have you any idos ofiagrossing the capital ! You mentioned that at the last meeting.
The Chsirman : Well, we have been loth to do it, but there is no doubt it must come sooner or later. We do not propose to make any change jast at present.

De Drysdale : I was very much plensed to hear the remarks of your colleagues about the rise in the price of land. Unfortunately, some years ago I was a shareholder in some of the Australian banks, and I have felt bow important it is to take the greatest care in times when the price of land is rising, beoanno buko are apt to lend out money too freely. I am also delighted to bear that Lord Milner is to be on your board. He is a director on the joint-stook bank with which I have to do. I hold a great many bank ebares, and I regard banks as the most civilising agency in the civilised world.
The resolation was then pat, and carried unanimously.
Lord Grenfell and Mr. Palmer were onanimously re-elected directors of the company.

Lord Grenfell: The very pleasant daty bas been given to me to propone that the Right Hon. Lord Milner should join the board, and I am glad to propose it, because in old day not such prosperous dayon at present1 bad the pleasure of working in Egypt with Lord Milner. I was then commanding the Egyptian Army ander certain diffi oulties and he was second in command to Lord Cromer in stroggling with the finance. I think our sbares then stood at from £19 to £16, and things in Egypt did not look very bright. We must aokoowledge that the great prosperity of our bank and the great prosperity in Bzypt is largely due to the exertioos made in those bad times by Lord Cromer, greatly assisted by the prerent Lord Milner, in reorganising the finances of Egypt and placing the whole financial system on the good basis on which it now rests. When Lord Milner's name was mentioned I think we saw how acceptable it would be to the sharebolders, and I have the greatest pl nasare in proposing bis election.

The Hoo. H.8. Carr Glyo: I have very great pleasure in secoading the resolation. I feel it is quite un Bossary for me to dwell in any way on the varied and illustrious career of Lord Milner after what bas fallen from Lord Gronfell, hesause I am sure he is well knowa to everyone in the room, aod I am sure his grest experience, fioanoial and general, and the great interest be takes in Baypt must be of great assistance to this board and must promote the prosperity of the company.
The resolation was carried unanimously.
The auditors (Messrs. Price, Waterhouse and Co.) were re-elected.

Captain Glyn: It gives me very mooh plesante to move that the thanks of the meeting be given to the chairman, directors, managers, and staff generally for their valuable services during the past year.

Mr. Payne: I have very much plessore in econding that resolation, and I should like also to include our thauks for the very inte resting and valuable information wbich has been given to us this afternoon.
The resolation was carried unanimously,
The Chairman: I am sure we are very much indebted to you for your kindness, and we sball try to produce as good balance-sboet next year, it not a better one.
The proceedings then terminated.

div.head: BEDRESHEIN
AN INTERESTING EXURSION
div.p: Bedreshein's chief olaim to notioe lies in the fact of its proximity to the remains of Mempbis; and in this respect it forms by far the easiert base for those who intend visiting the site of this once celebrated and enormous oity. The fall etation lies but an boor's run from the E. S. R. station Cairo, on the main line to Loxor, the train taking the wide detour throngh Boalao across the river, past Bmbabeh, and on to Ghizeb, leaving the Pyramid of Cheone Kephron, eto, on the right, and the distant Citadel, the Mokattam bille, with their row of towers, eto, on the left. A procession of boats with their vast sails stretebed to catch the breeze drift silently up and down the river ; various other pyramids on the Libyan plain mark the site of that hoge necropolis which onoe stretched all the way from Ghireh to Bakkarab, Abougir, Dashoor, and even for her still. A continuous grove of palm trees beside the railway line between Ghizeh and Bedresbein station bides muob of the distant view, but the blue sky, the palms, and the son-bine glinting on the rich crops below; the floks of goate, beer, gamoore and their sbepherds, are welcome sights to those whose eyes are wesried with the towa life of Cairo.

Bedre-hein station is but a few minutes walk from the village; and though the gnidebook deolares there is not much of interest in the place, it well repay, « leign relyssnnter through its streets. Though boilt of ann dried bricks, roofed with the antidy bundles of sugar osne straw and stack of the common foal of the country, eraoted at hap.bazard and minus every rudiment of comfort, these dative abops sod houses never cease to be picturesque AQcessories to the soene and fitting complements to the surrounding land-oape. Ssonter through there oneven mod streets and I dety anyone to find the process boring. There are shops of divers sorte, there are groups of dignified people, and no more delightfol groups of ondigified cbildren awaiting attention at every turn. Tarn your mental camers upon the narrow court ways as yon pass, register the impression of the aunlight streaming down into a corner rieb with onpre. meditated piotare q eness and Andreamt of dirt, glance into the dark interiora where obild and animal life lie hu idled olose, watch for an instant wbere the little obildren of the sun are at their glory, watch the change in the expression when they recogaizg the presence of a stranger and the possibility of backab terb, and you will never complain of dolness again.

Footpaths are unknown in Bedresbein as in most other native villages : the pedestrian must take bis obanoe along with the rest of the world, and the unwary one may, like as not, fiod bis way disputed by a string of snarling, iodependent camels whose claim to! the road is as good and much more foroible than his own. Real tourists in un belmets and blue veils riding astride on woe-begone donkeys are apt to obtrude themselves on Boones where their presence is an apaobroniem, and rudely distarbing to the harmony of the composition.

Through the village the road runs along a winding embankment to the mounds near Mitrabening, mounds which, if looal bearsay is oorreot, mark part of the very site of Memphis. Indeed many of the important quarters and buildings of the city appear to bave stood in the very fields and village of Bedresbein itself, so that it is quite possible that our tourist feet may be tramping onder neath the soil which once was covered ages ago by tbe gardens, villas, or sacred groves of Maryé-men-nofer. The history of Memphis, is it not written large in every guide book on Egypt, and the article upon the same subject which appeared but recently in the colours of one of our contemporaries makes it diffi salt to mention the subject without committing the deadly sin of plagiarism. In tsot nothing remains to be said about Memphis and its temples, its gods and its rolers, ita monuments and its remains, but what has been said and desoribed many many time before.

Bat modern Badrasbein, thongh small and of Do particular reputation, may pereh snoe offer consolations of its owo not to be discover ed among tombs and borial grounds. It is & fairly typiosl native town and thoogh within easy distance of Cairo bas been bat little touched by Earopean influences. Ito immediate surroundings are quiet and peacefal and of a Sylvan character. Here you may see the modern prototypes of Jacob at the well, Rsobel' tending her flooks; and though, it they are near enough, they will probably abandon their doties and olamour loadly for baksbeesb, if they are beyond speaking distance their attitude and por. suits will be strangely in keeping with one's early Biblical training. The wik from the river' edge is just long enough for an easy stroll, a classical ferry boat in consideration for modest fee will kindly transport one to the other side where the latest thing in tea bouse chale's, San Giovanni," will welcome one with all the material com Horts Deoghary. The retorn jour ey from thence may either be mada by returning Boross the river to B dreshen from wbence various trains may be taken to Cairo; or else by motor or to Halonan station and o to the Bab el Lok terminus of the Delta Light Railway.

div.head: THE OASIS OF SIWA
A KHEDIVIAL VISIT
div.p: (Continued from yesterday.) The Hama le, i.e., stony desert, was passed and with the new day appeared green land with rubble and with many Ghartas (sand danes). It was delightful to walk over this westber-beated ground. Tho osmels tramped at a rate of six kilometres per hour in the cool, early morning, & speed we seldom attained later on. My diary, which reports every 1/4 bour on the swiftness of my oamel, records an average of 87 steps per minute, bat on this morning from 96.160 Afrer Kapais the tra veller follows one of those darrow paths of wbich occasionally as many as twenty five ron along at sbort distances from each other. If, hitherto, there was seldom any trace of a road visible, it gave you now tbe impression that it must be quite simple thing to oross the fearinspiring desert along these paths, though, be It onderstood, this is only the base in those months when the caravans trading in dates lesve such traces behind and aplarge the stone-pyramide bearing way.marks. A wellequipped Boropean would ron very little danger, as he would alwys meet with four wel's after having passed Kanais, namely, Bir L bager, Bir Hkfet egge'a Bir Helo, and Br Istable. The first named would be a great attraction to the arobaeologist, because you can recognizin it the fortifications already mentioned. Unfortunately, though, only abort balt is possible at such expored spots. However, the construction of the Kbedivial motor track to Siwa will, in the rear fatore, off the specialist opportunity to explore hid-1 Hen tressdres, as this motor-track will touch all the ancient placos.

What appears most imposing to the Bedouing Jis Bir Hakfet ezgetas, a large, rich waterbasin with plenty of strooo and black-lead, and in its neighbourhood there are traces of habitations wbich speak of a time when the I place was more thickly populated. The cover of the well, supported by a massive pillar, is, bare also, partly fallen in, and the wide, watery surface looks most inviting to the thirsty traveller. About two boors to the south, i.e., six hours distant from Kinais: the frequently deceived ey, fancies it e-pies a lake sneh as the wanderer bas of en been deluded with by Pata Morgana (virage). It was a glad surprise to meet, at short distapoes, two big weet water lakes (raia water) W. learned on making enquiries that the latter were parts of a far-stretohing lako which diminished in circumference in the beight of the summer. This lake stretches from West to East and a second one lies close to it farther South Before entering apon this region we notioed large cavities in the ground in the form of basins, all the more 80 88 there are wild-ducks flying all around. Between the last of these water basins, upknown up to the present, and Bir Hela, we oross the bighest part of the Libyan platesa.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demio.) Toute l'attention de marché a été absorbée ce matin par l'Urbaine, qui bénéficie de os obef d'ane atado de 8/16 & 7 8/8 l'ancienne et 71/16 la nouvelle
Éa demande tres active la National Bank progresse de 27 11/16 à 28, acheteurs.
Bo hausse onoore, quoique foios accentuée, la Belt & Soda 91/9, les Nongovich à 29 18/16, le Cheikh Fadlá 104, la fondateur Comptoir
88/4, la Building Lands á 5 7/8 et les Ootton Gionen 1 15/16.
On sobète la Bébés à 40, Is Nile Landa 93 8/4, l'Investment à 1 3/16, les Estates à | 7/16 et le Banco di Roma á 116.
Par contre, l'action Comptoir fléchit à 7 3/8 l'ancienne et 7 1/16 la nouvelle, l'Upper Egypt | and Delta Navigation à 5 1/16 et l'Union Fon cière à 6 1/16.
Tout le reste de la cote est sans obangement.

Comme on le voit par le bret exposé ci-dessar, la tendance est bien meilleure. On se montre généralement plein d'espoir dans le mois de mars, et c'est ce qui explique la facilité avec laquella s'opèrent les reporte. Les transactions proprement dites sont d'ailleurs limitées, taut à cause de la pénurie monétaire que de la répognanoe des établissements de orédit à consentir de nouvelles avaD008.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de I'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance da Pablio qu'elle recevra jarqo'an landi 8 Avril 1907 à midi, des offres pour la fourniture de 86,000 Traversos courtes en bois de Sapia conformément aux Conditione da Cabier des Charges dont on peut obtenir un exemplaire au Service des Magasins Géoéraux à Boulao (Caire) et Gabbary (Alexandrie) contre paiement de 100 millièmes.
Los soumissionnaires auront à joindre à leur offre un réoépissé constatant le versement à la Caisse de l'Administration d'an dépot provisoire de LE. 100.
Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de 80 millièmes: Biles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recom mandé à :
Monsieur le Directeur Général Chemins de fer de l'Etat,
(Caire) et soge double a voloppe, l'intérieure portant la sasoription suivante :
"Offre poar 85000 traverses courtes en bois de Sapin."
L'Administration ne s'engage pas accepter les prix les plas élevés, ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées ; elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande.
Le Caire, le 28 Février 1907. 29649 2 1
AVIS

Dans le but d'assurer la plas grande disponibilité possible ser les plateformes de Gebe! el Zeitoon (Gabbary.) et afin de pouvoir y recevoir la plas grande quantité possible d'oi goods at augmenter ainsi les facilités accordées aux négociants de cet article, la Direction Générales l'honneur d'aviser le Pablio que dorénavant le délai de franchise pour le retrait des expéditions d'oignons de Gabbary sera de 19 heures.
Les expéditions non retirées dans le dit délai seront passibles des droits de magasinage fixés par l'art 85 do Tarif des Marobandises.
Le Caire, le 27 Février 1907. 99669 2.1
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de fer et Télégraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter à LOODDRIS Doe da Publio qn' partir do ler Mars proohain, le Bareau Télégraphique de Sombat, station da Chemin de fer do Delts, Bors onvert pour l'échange des télégrammes on langues Earopéennes pour l'intérieur de l'Egypte.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
Liverpool, February 91. There has been a fairly active market this week for Spot Egyptians, and prices are very steady, the quotations of both Brown and Uppers being raised to to , per lb.
Paturos have been moderately active and the following are the latest values.
Feb. 11.6 May 10,57 Aug. 10.44 Mar. 11.8 June 10.52 Sept. 10.38 April 10.61 July 10.48 Oot. 10.94

Nov. 10.03 AMERICAN FUTUREs. The trading this week has been very lifeless and quite confined to the professional element, whilst the long continued apathy of the pablio exerts a subdoing it fence, and tires the outside speculator. The "Balls" have shown rather more disposition to become "Besrish", on the other hand Mr. Theodore Price cables: "Digestive Crop 18,000,000 bales maximom, probably less." This would suggest a bullish view of the situation, bat mesuwbile the figures look as if it would be more than that. Spianers continue to buy fairly freely.

The closing quotations show one point decline for dese, and to 6 points advance tor distant position, the latest delivery are :February 5.66 May/Jane 5.58 Sap/Ost. 5.49 Feb./Mar. 5.611 Jane/Jaly 5.57 0ot./Nov. 5.451 Mar./Apl. 5.60 July/Aag 5.55 Nov./Dec. 5 45 Apl./May 5.59 Ang/Sep.5.51 Deo/Jx. 5.45

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
